comments.body:
kvutils should probably provide a canonical way to allocate a random entry id with enough entropy. This way of allocating doesn't provide enough entropy. For the in-memory and SQL implementations we might want to consider just allocating the ids sequentially.

kvutils also doesn't currently declare the outputs as inputs and hence does not check for conflicts on outputs itself (e.g. we might end up overwriting an existing log entry!). We might want to consider doing this check in kvutils itself. FYI @miklos-da.

It does have the downside that we end up doing more fetches for keys that we expect not to exist and depending on the ledger we might have other options for detecting the conflict (e.g. allocating entry ids in a conflict free way).
You're right about just using sequential IDs here. Will fix at some point.
Regarding the checks, I think it's a good idea. Perhaps the implementation can decide whether to add it to the list of inputs or not.

comments.body: The operations below (read / update state) should be performed in a single transaction.

They are. We `setAutoCommit(false)` below, which means everything happens in a transaction. Acquiring the connection starts the transaction, and closing it implicitly commits. I'm not a big fan of implicit behavior, so [`withConnection`](https://github.com/digital-asset/daml/pull/3940/files#diff-9f45aadbe621258428069b8880a87344R160) explicitly commits if all goes well. It also catches exceptions and explicitly rolls back.
Let's rename this to `inTransaction`.
I'd suggest adding `DB` or `Database` (e.g. `inDbTransaction`) to the name as well. There are enough different kinds of transactions that warrant making it super clear which one is meant.
Thanks for the clarification regarding transactions @SamirTalwar.
Renamed it to `inDatabaseTransaction`, and renamed the other `withConnection` to `withDatabaseStream`.
